title: Where can I sell my own lyrics of my own songs? - Quora

response.answer_text: While there are people who are super talented at writing lyrics, it’s something that most people can do to a certain extent, so unless you can also write songs, it’s not that likely that you’ll be able to sell lyrics alone. Instead what you should look for is composers that don’t feel comfortable with writing lyrics, to collaborate with. Try West Coast Songwriters, or similar organizations. Go to places with open mic nights to mingle. Post on related boards (physical boards and online boards) related to songwriting and put it out there that you’re looking for someone to collaborate with. I’ve always wished I could do this sort of thing - not because I thought I could make a living out of it, but because I enjoy writing song lyrics. However, I can admit to myself that sometimes things I write have cheesy parts that make me groan, and I also know that lots of pop and country lyrics out there could have been written by pretty much anybody with some skills. Or, maybe I am really good at it and I’ve missed out on some opportunity because I didn’t have enough faith or desire to do music. If you want to find out, the only way is to delve into researching the music business and start making connections now. Good luck.

Hi! I agree very much with both comments. I’ve been in the songwriting and music publishing business’ for over a decade and I don’t know of any instances where someone’s lyrics were “sold.” If you’re simply interested in selling your lyrics as is, as John Pape said…that’s technically poetry…but you can absolutely try to do that! If you’re more interested in having your lyrics used in a song(s), I would recommend co writing. I have many friends who only write lyrics that make a fine living as songwriters! Here’s a link to a story on Liz Rose. She is a lyricist (doesn’t play an instrument) and co-worte almost every song on Taylor Swift’s first album! The Story of Liz Rose… Inspiring!!! How to find co-writers…that’s a whole different topic. Go to singer/songwriter nights at local venues, join songwriting organizations, etc. I hope this was helpful - good luck!
